{{also|kënnen}} ==Cornish== ===Alternative forms=== * {{qualifier|Revived Late Cornish}} {{l|kw|kednen}} ===Etymology=== From {{affix|kw|kenn|gloss1=peel, scum, skin|-en}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|Revived Middle Cornish}} {{IPA|kw|[kɛnːɛn]}} ===Noun=== {{kw-noun|m|kennow}} # {{l|en|film}}, {{l|en|membrane}} ====Mutation==== {{kw mut cons|k|ennen}} ---- ==Dutch== ===Etymology=== {{PIE root|nl|ǵneh₃}} From {{inh|nl|dum|kennen}}, from {{inh|nl|odt|kennen}}, from {{inh|nl|gem-pro|*kannijaną}}, from {{der|nl|ine-pro|*ǵneh₃-}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nl|/ˈkɛnə(n)/}} * {{audio|nl|Nl-kennen.ogg|audio}} * {{hyphenation|nl|ken|nen}} * {{rhymes|nl|ɛnən}} ===Verb=== {{nl-verb}} # {{lb|nl|transitive}} to [[know]] (a person, a thing), be [[acquainted]] with # {{lb|nl|auxiliary|colloquial|dialectal}} {{synonym of|nl|kunnen}} ====Inflection==== {{nl-conj-wk|ken|kenne}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|nl|bekennen}} * {{l|nl|erkennen}} * {{l|nl|herkennen}} * {{l|nl|kenmerk}} * {{l|nl|miskennen}} * {{l|nl|ontkennen}} * {{l|nl|toekennen}} * {{l|nl|verkennen}} ====Descendants==== * {{desc|af|ken}} ====See also==== * {{l|nl|weten}} ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== {{PIE root|de|ǵneh₃}} From {{inh|de|goh|kennan}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*kannijaną||to know}}. Cognate to {{cog|nl|kennen}}, {{cog|sco|-}} and {{cog|en|ken||to know}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈkɛnən/}} * {{audio|de|De-kennen.ogg|audio (Germany)}} * {{audio|de|De-at-kennen.ogg|audio (Austria)}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-weak|class=|kennt|kannte|gekannt|past subjunctive=kennte}} # {{lb|de|transitive}} to [[know]]; to be acquainted with; to be familiar with ====Usage notes==== * Although the senses of both ''kennen'' and {{m|de|wissen}} are covered by English “to know”, the two German verbs are only occasionally interchangeable. ''Wissen'' is used with facts and memorized information (“to be aware of”), whereas ''kennen'' is used with people, places, concepts, etc. (“to be familiar with”). As a fallible rule of thumb, one can say that ''wissen'' corresponds to English “to know” + subclause and “to know of”, while ''kennen'' corresponds to “to know” + direct object. * The past subjunctive ''kennte'' is very rare in contemporary German. It should be used with great caution even in the most formal register. ====Conjugation==== {{de-conj-auto|k|ennen}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|auskennen}} * {{l|de|bekennen}} * {{l|de|erkennen}} * {{l|de|kennenlernen}}, {{l|de|kennen lernen}} * {{l|de|Kenntnis}} * {{l|de|Kennung}} * {{l|de|Kennzeichen}} * {{l|de|verkennen}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:German irregular verbs]] ---- ==Low German== ===Etymology=== {{PIE root|nds|ǵneh₃}} Cognate with German and Dutch [[kennen]], English [[ken]]. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nds|/ˈkɛnnən/}} ===Verb=== {{head|nds|verb}} # {{lb|nds|transitive}} to [[know]] (someone); to be acquainted with # {{lb|nds|transitive}} to [[know]] (some fact); to have knowledge of ====Conjugation==== {{nds-conj-wk|kenn|kenn|kenn|kenn|kenn}} ====Synonyms==== * {{sense|to know a fact}} {{l|nds|weten}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|nds|bekennen}} * {{l|nds|kennen lehren}} * {{l|nds|Kenntnis}} * {{l|nds|Kennen}} * {{l|nds|Kennteken}} * {{l|nds|utkennen}} * {{l|nds|verkennen}} ---- ==Luxembourgish== ===Etymology=== {{PIE root|lb|ǵneh₃}} From {{inh|lb|goh|kennan}}, from {{inh|lb|gem-pro|*kannijaną}}. Cognate with {{cog|de|kennen}}, {{cog|nl|kennen}}, {{cog|en|ken}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|lb|/ˈkænən/}} * {{rhymes|lb|ænən}} ===Verb=== {{lb-verb||kannt}} # {{lb|lb|transitive}} to [[know]] ====Conjugation==== {{lb-conj-regular|kenn|kannt|hunn}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|lb|auskennen}} * {{l|lb|bekennen}} * {{l|lb|erkennen}} * {{l|lb|verkennen}} ---- ==Middle Dutch== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|dum|odt|kennen}}, from {{inh|dum|gem-pro|*kannijaną}}, from {{der|dum|ine-pro|*ǵneh₃-}}. ===Verb=== {{dum-verb}} # to [[know]], to be [[familiar]] with # to [[recognise]], to know who/what someone/something is # to [[recognise]], to [[acknowledge]] (a fact) # to [[admit]] # to [[consider]] (to be) # to [[establish]] (as fact) ====Inflection==== {{rfinfl|dum|verb}} ====Descendants==== * {{desc|nl|kennen}} * {{desc|li|kènne}}, {{l|li|kinne}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:VMNW|ID64952}} * {{R:MNW|21118}} ---- ==Old Dutch== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|odt|gem-pro|*kannijaną}}. ===Verb=== {{odt-verb}} # to [[know]], to be [[aware]] of ====Inflection==== {{rfinfl|odt|verb}}{{cln|odt|class 1 weak verbs}} ====Descendants==== * {{desctree|dum|kennen}} ====Further reading==== * {{R:ONW|1056}}
